author: HinduHamma
body:
Uncharted territory my fucking ass. 

All the sp500 has ever done is make new ATHs time after time , crash after crash. This time is not any different. This is normal. The speed at which it is recovering is also normal because every market participant knows the story of past US recessions and economic downturn - they know if you sell your holdings, you’ll regret it down the road. So what’s the point of selling right now if your actually investing for years, decades? None. Especially when it’s super easy to get a loan for rock bottom rates, cash is very accessible for all the big boy investors and institutions. 

Everyone constantly downvoted bulls in March for even thinking that a V shape market recovery was gonna happen, for ever thinking we were gonna see ATHs again this year. Don’t worry I haven’t forgotten. There’s a lot of remind me bot posts I got coming due soon from March . 

Once again bears, hold this L . Scoreboard don’t lie. You never win consistently. Keep being wrong and stay salty about this. I’m sorry you missed out on the greatest 50 day rally in stock market history. That’s gonna be a good story to tell your grand kids at least.

author: BrokerBrody
body:
>Everyone constantly downvoted bulls in March for even thinking that a V shape market recovery was gonna happen, f

Don't want to sound like a perma-bull; but, there is absolutely no evidence that a V shaped recovery is happening.

I'm not saying that it can't happen; but, we are barely beginning the recovery phase (when many businesses like CCL or LYV have rallied to the moon and yet to even reopen) and we don't know if we will shoot straight up or the recovery will fizzle out.

I don't want to tell anyone to be fearful when others are greedy and that bullshit because what Reddit thinks often has no correlation with reality inverse or otherwise; but, this post is very much premature celebration.

author: Smok3dSalmon
body:
The market is going to be fucked.

**Hedge funds are tricking stupid retail investors and actually** ***charging*** **retail investors for the right to hold the fund's bags.**

Look at what happened to American Airlines between June 4th and June 12th. The stock opened on June 4th at 16.74 and closed on the 12th at 16.74. All of the price movement happened during early market. From the 4th to the 12th the high and low was 21.67 to 14.07. That's INSANE.

&#x200B;

Here is a timeline of what happened on the 11th to 12th.

1. Wednesday we close at around $17.
2. Thursday morning, 9M shares are dumped to tank AAL in early market trading.
3. Market opens and some(not all) retail panics and dump shares.
4. Hedge fund spends part of the day buying shares as retail users dump them in a panic.
5. Friday morning, someone buys 9M shares to pump the stock up to Wednesday's close of $17.
6. Retail has been trained that when a stock is up big, it's going to close even higher. So, of course they start buying the shit out of AAL.
7. Hedge fund sells all of Thursday's shares at a cool 13% gain (14.75->16.75)

Hedge funds are just flipping shares from 1 day to the next while maintaining cash positions. What a fucking great way to make money.

&#x200B;

Edit: [Video of Cramer admitting that he did this.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VMuEis3byY4)

Trump signing executive order to suspend h-1b visas (Visa-holders already in the U.S. and those applicants who have already received a visa are exempt from the ban).  https://techcrunch.com/2020/06/22/president-trump-reportedly-will-sign-executive-order-temporarily-suspending-work-visas-for-h-1b-holders/

I don't really know shit about dick, so I could be way off, but I actually think curtailing the h-1b program long term is bad for America.  I work for a big tech company and when they first started pulling back on the visas, we just went to India and opened an office there. The reason I think it's bad for America is because now instead of these workers coming to the US, being paid USD, paying US taxes, and spending money on US soil, all of that money just stays in India.

author: Tendieheart_Bear
body:
The Stages of Reopening (update):

Week 0 - Excitement - "OMG we're back!!"

Week 1 - Euphoria - "SPY 300+, I heard there's lines at some place!! V-shaped recovery!!"

Week 2 - Realization - "hindsight, lockdowns were stupid. Probably caused more harm than it prevented"

Week 3 - Concern - "okay the lines are shorter now, I participated in going out, it was meh.. it was slow and awkward, maybe it comes back?"

* Most of you are here (now with rioting)

Week 4 - Growing Concern - "These places are empty... How are they going to make it on 25% capacity, assuming they're even seeing that? No one is getting rehired, in fact they'll probably need to let more go."

Week 5 - Full Bear - "Okay, this is slower than I remember 2009 being. I don't think it's bouncing back. SPY levels totally not sustainable, WTF were we thinking!?!"

Week 6 (**New**) - Joining the Poors - "I thought my white collar job was safe, but the company is being more dick now than they were when we were under lockdown.  I think they retained people just to cultivate good PR during the crisis, but are ready to release employees"

author: thewhyofpi
body:
I'm one of "those Tesla ultra bulls" who think in 12 years the stock will be at $50.000 and nevertheless, I sold all my TSLA stocks (well I kept 1 for sentimental reasons). My three main reasons are:

1.) Today, Tesla only produces around 400.000 cars per year. I believe they do earn a lot of money for each car they sell, but still that is not enough to justify a market cap of 188 billion. Toyota produces about 9 million cars per year and has a market cap of 179 billion. So yeah, TSLA is a bit overvalued.   


2.) Global pandemic. I don't see it "solved" right now. We think the worst is over. I see second wave in fall/winter. Everyone is assuring there will never be a second lockdown. I'm not so sure about that either. The quick V shaped recovery could rather be a deep W shaped slow recovery. Oh and the whole Trump-China thing, the Hong Kong-China thing, Hard Brexit and return of the Euro crisis. A lot of risks that is not priced in into the stocks thanks to the central banks printing money.   


3.) Too much greed. My spider senses are tingeling and I have a strange dot-com boom deja-vu. I hear and read about a lot of people talking about getting into the stock market, and how easy it is to make huge profits in a few days. People who usually don't care about stocks, and are rather risk averse consider signing up on an online broker and join the party. 

So yeah, my profits that I made with selling the shares (in Jan-Feb) could have been way bigger if I just would have kept them, but we will see how this turns out. If I'm wrong and we really have put the worst of 2020 behind us, I'm a happy person. I'll get back into Tesla and wait the next 10 years for how it develops

author: butterylotad
body:
This is really bad. I'm not even concerned about my portfolio or whatever at this point. I'm far more concerned for the short-midterm outlook of the many families out there that will lose a lot. 

I think this is the key sentence: 

>The total number of people claiming benefits in all programs for the week ending May 23 was 29,505,027, a decrease of 662,143 from the previous week. There were 1,545,606 persons claiming benefits in all programs in the comparable week in 2019. 

What we were hoping for was a pseudo V-shaped recovery (not that it was reasonable) which would mean that right around this time, we'd see a huge spike in employment because things are going back to normal in many places. In contrast, it only went down 600k. We should be hoping for better.

author: -AUTISTICUS_MAXIMUS-
body:
The Federal Reserve Board on Thursday released the results of its stress tests for 2020 and additional sensitivity analyses that the Board conducted in light of the coronavirus event.

"The banking system has been a source of strength during this crisis," Vice Chair Randal K. Quarles said, "and the results of our sensitivity analyses show that our banks can remain strong in the face of even the harshest shocks."

In addition to its normal stress test, the Board conducted a sensitivity analysis to assess the resiliency of large banks under three hypothetical recessions, or downside scenarios, which could result from the coronavirus event. The scenarios included a V-shaped recession and recovery; a slower, U-shaped recession and recovery; and a W-shaped, double-dip recession.

In the three downside scenarios, the unemployment rate peaked at between 15.6 percent and 19.5 percent, which is significantly more stringent than any of the Board's pre-coronavirus stress test scenarios. The scenarios are not predictions or forecasts of the likely path of the economy or financial markets.

In aggregate, loan losses for the 34 banks ranged from $560 billion to $700 billion in the sensitivity analysis and aggregate capital ratios declined from 12.0 percent in the fourth quarter of 2019 to between 9.5 percent and 7.7 percent under the hypothetical downside scenarios. Under the U- and W-shaped scenarios, most firms remain well capitalized but several would approach minimum capital levels. The sensitivity analysis does not incorporate the potential effects of government stimulus payments and expanded unemployment insurance.

In light of these results, the Board took several actions following its stress tests to ensure large banks remain resilient despite the economic uncertainty from the coronavirus event. For the third quarter of this year, the Board is requiring large banks to preserve capital by suspending share repurchases, capping dividend payments, and allowing dividends according to a formula based on recent income. The Board is also requiring banks to re-evaluate their longer-term capital plans.

All large banks will be required to resubmit and update their capital plans later this year to reflect current stresses, which will help firms re-assess their capital needs and maintain strong capital planning practices during this period of uncertainty. The Board will conduct additional analysis each quarter to determine if adjustments to this response are appropriate.

During the third quarter, no share repurchases will be permitted. In recent years, share repurchases have represented approximately 70 percent of shareholder payouts from large banks. The Board is also capping dividend payments to the amount paid in the second quarter and is further limiting them to an amount based on recent earnings. As a result, a bank cannot increase its dividend and can pay dividends if it has earned sufficient income.

The Board also released the results of its full stress test designed before the coronavirus. The results from that test are comparable to the V-shaped downside scenario in the sensitivity analysis, in aggregate, and show that all large banks remain strongly capitalized. The Board will use the results of this test to set the new stress capital buffer requirement for these firms, which will take effect, as planned, in the fourth quarter. Additionally, the Board will not be objecting to five foreign banks whose capital planning practices were evaluated as part of the stress tests.

author: taedrin
body:
>One of the major design flaws in its construction is that it is not actually anchored to the bedrock below it.

This isn't a design flaw, it is a consideration for the engineering of the dam.  Most dams (even in the US) are not anchored to the bedrock underneath.

> This would mean that water could flow under the dam structure, eroding  the earth that is keeping it in place, and essentially cause it to  collapse under the force of its own gravity. 

All dams have a certain amount of water flowing underneath of them.  It is only a problem if the rate of flow is high enough to overcome the shear strength of the soil that the dam rests on.  You can reduce the rate of flow by increasing the distance the water must flow to get under the dam, such as by constructing a cutoff wall.  See [this](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eImtYyuQCZ8) Practical Engineering video where seepage is demonstrated both with and without a cutoff wall.

author: nduxx
body:
Yeah but secularly, airlines are a garbage business. Think about it:

1. Individuals traveling for pleasure is totally non-essential; they only do it if it's cheap. It's cheap for them because business travel exists. But business travel is becoming increasingly non-essential. Nothing replaces face-to-face but culture is coming around to normalizing teleconferencing (it already was even before the pandemic, but the timeline moved up a lot now).
2. The industry is regulated to an insane level. There's only so much you can do to differentiate yourself or cut costs. Meanwhile government keeps making the experience even more miserable every passing year, and maybe there will be carbon taxes in the future. 
3. There's massive political risk in the form of travel restrictions, visa restrictions, etc.
4. There's a ton of countries with state owned carries which are subsidized to stupid levels as part of PR plays for corrupt regimes. How are you supposed to compete with an oil backed carrier on long haul flights to Asia or Europe? Nobody knows.
5. It's a very capital intensive business. Planes are super expensive, even if you can offload some of the risk by leasing them instead of owning them.
6. The biggest marginal cost is fuel. The price of oil can vary wildly based on the whims of despots halfway around the world. Sure you can hedge with futures, but hedging isn't free.

Compare this with something like tech (near zero marginal costs, crazy profit margins) or healthcare (insanely inelastic demand) you can see why this is a shit business to invest in.

body:
>Everyone constantly downvoted bulls in March for even thinking that a V shape market recovery was gonna happen, f

Don't want to sound like a perma-bull; but, there is absolutely no evidence that a V shaped recovery is happening.

I'm not saying that it can't happen; but, we are barely beginning the recovery phase (when many businesses like CCL or LYV have rallied to the moon and yet to even reopen) and we don't know if we will shoot straight up or the recovery will fizzle out.

I don't want to tell anyone to be fearful when others are greedy and that bullshit because what Reddit thinks often has no correlation with reality inverse or otherwise; but, this post is very much premature celebration.

author: thewhyofpi
body:
I'm one of "those Tesla ultra bulls" who think in 12 years the stock will be at $50.000 and nevertheless, I sold all my TSLA stocks (well I kept 1 for sentimental reasons). My three main reasons are:

1.) Today, Tesla only produces around 400.000 cars per year. I believe they do earn a lot of money for each car they sell, but still that is not enough to justify a market cap of 188 billion. Toyota produces about 9 million cars per year and has a market cap of 179 billion. So yeah, TSLA is a bit overvalued.   


2.) Global pandemic. I don't see it "solved" right now. We think the worst is over. I see second wave in fall/winter. Everyone is assuring there will never be a second lockdown. I'm not so sure about that either. The quick V shaped recovery could rather be a deep W shaped slow recovery. Oh and the whole Trump-China thing, the Hong Kong-China thing, Hard Brexit and return of the Euro crisis. A lot of risks that is not priced in into the stocks thanks to the central banks printing money.   


3.) Too much greed. My spider senses are tingeling and I have a strange dot-com boom deja-vu. I hear and read about a lot of people talking about getting into the stock market, and how easy it is to make huge profits in a few days. People who usually don't care about stocks, and are rather risk averse consider signing up on an online broker and join the party. 

So yeah, my profits that I made with selling the shares (in Jan-Feb) could have been way bigger if I just would have kept them, but we will see how this turns out. If I'm wrong and we really have put the worst of 2020 behind us, I'm a happy person. I'll get back into Tesla and wait the next 10 years for how it develops

piece of article that came out in barrons today. 'The S&P 500 Has Erased Its 2020 Losses. The Fed's Money FLood Suggests Room to Run'. "Fed Chairman Jerome Powell has pledged to do more, assuring investors that the central bank has more firepower and is willing to use it. Aside from the surprise rise in payrolls, personal income grew 10.5% in April and the savings rate jumped to 33%. That’s as initial jobless claims, while still high, have continued their weekly decline, manufacturing surveys beat expectations, May auto sales improved, and mortgage applications increased for the seventh straight week. 

Deeper down, Shalett says, Fed-driven liquidity is booming in a way that can help sustain asset prices. “All told, this strong data validates the market narrative of a V-shaped recovery,” Shalett says. " by Lisa Beilfuss

author: Tendieheart_Bear
body:
The Stages of Reopening (update):

Week 0 - Excitement - "OMG we're back!!"

Week 1 - Euphoria - "SPY 300+, I heard there's lines at some place!! V-shaped recovery!!"

Week 2 - Realization - "hindsight, lockdowns were stupid. Probably caused more harm than it prevented"

Week 3 - Concern - "okay the lines are shorter now, I participated in going out, it was meh.. it was slow and awkward, maybe it comes back?"

Week 4 - Growing Concern - "These places are empty... How are they going to make it on 25% capacity, assuming they're even seeing that? No one is getting rehired, in fact they'll probably need to let more go."

- Next week!

Week 5 - Full Bear - "Okay, this is slower than I remember 2009 being. I don't think it's bouncing back. SPY levels totally not sustainable, WTF were we thinking!?!"

Week 6 - Joining the Poors - "I thought my white collar job was safe, but the company is being more dick now than they were when we were under lockdown.  I think they retained people just to cultivate good PR during the crisis, but are ready to release employees"

Week 7 - WTF!? -

author: nduxx
body:
Yeah but secularly, airlines are a garbage business. Think about it:

1. Individuals traveling for pleasure is totally non-essential; they only do it if it's cheap. It's cheap for them because business travel exists. But business travel is becoming increasingly non-essential. Nothing replaces face-to-face but culture is coming around to normalizing teleconferencing (it already was even before the pandemic, but the timeline moved up a lot now).
2. The industry is regulated to an insane level. There's only so much you can do to differentiate yourself or cut costs. Meanwhile government keeps making the experience even more miserable every passing year, and maybe there will be carbon taxes in the future. 
3. There's massive political risk in the form of travel restrictions, visa restrictions, etc.
4. There's a ton of countries with state owned carries which are subsidized to stupid levels as part of PR plays for corrupt regimes. How are you supposed to compete with an oil backed carrier on long haul flights to Asia or Europe? Nobody knows.
5. It's a very capital intensive business. Planes are super expensive, even if you can offload some of the risk by leasing them instead of owning them.
6. The biggest marginal cost is fuel. The price of oil can vary wildly based on the whims of despots halfway around the world. Sure you can hedge with futures, but hedging isn't free.

Compare this with something like tech (near zero marginal costs, crazy profit margins) or healthcare (insanely inelastic demand) you can see why this is a shit business to invest in.

author: chinchalinchin
body:
So everyone seems to be giving you  some folksy financial wisdom based on their "gut intuition". It's  important to keep in mind markets are reflexive in the sense that retail  traders can influence the price of equities in the short term through  their sentiment, but in the long term, prices tend to be driven by data  models adopted by large institutional investors, such as hedge funds,  pensions, sovereign wealth funds, etc. In order to get an idea of what a  person of the latter ilk might say about the current level of the  SP500, let's do a little analysis.

Let's  say you are a company and you have a stream of cash flows, let's call  each it C, that occur every quarter for the rest of time. What is the  present value of that cash flow? You discount each cash flow back to the  present according to the prevailing quarterly [cost of capital](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/w/wacc.asp), let's call it r1.

C + C/(1+r1) + C/(1+r1)\^2 + ... forever and ever.

Mathematically, this is [geometric sum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometric_series)

.  You can show this is equal to C/(1- 1/(1+r1)), or simplified, C (1+r1) /  r1 = C ( 1/r1 + 1). Note the present value of the cash flow is  inversely proportional to the cost of capital. As the cost of capital  goes up, the present value goes down and visa versa.

If  the cost of capital then drops to, say, r2, the present value of that  cash flow goes up to C (1/r2 +1). The percentage increase in the value  of the cash flow would then be,

\[C \* ( 1/r2 + 1)  - C \* ( 1/r1 + 1) \] / C(1/r1 +1 ) =

(1/r2 + 1) / (1/r1 + 1 ) - 1

Cool.  So we have a formula that tells us what the percentage change in a  perpetual quarterly cash flow should be in terms of the quarterly cost  of capital. Let's make so simplifying assumptions (I will comment on  these assumptions a little later on, but for now, just go with it.)

Let's  assume your company earns revenue annually instead of quarterly (this  assumption doesn't really matter that much since you can just treat the  amalgamation of quarterly earnings over a year as a single entity, and  it makes the math easier). Let's assume your company can borrow at the  risk-free rate, i.e. the US treasury yield. Let's assume this is your  company's only source of financing. Let's use the 10 year yield, since  we are dealing with long term cash flows. How much did the present value  of your cash flows go up when the Fed lowered the interest rate back in  March?

In Feb, the 10 year rate  was roughly 1.6%. It is currently roughly 0.9%. US treasuries are  semi-annual, so if we concert these to annual rates, that's roughly 3.2%  and 1.8% respectively. The percentage increase in the present value of  your annual cashflow is then,

(1/0.018 + 1) / (1/0.032 + 1 ) - 1 = 0.75 = 75%.

The  value of your cash flow went up a staggering 75%! If your cash flow was  worth 1 million dollars, then it's now worth 1.75 million dollars. Now,  onto some commentary and explanation.

Analysts working in institutions value companies by [making  projections for a firm's earnings and then discounting those  projections back to the present by the firm's cost of capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discounted_cash_flow)

.  Which is exactly the calculation we've just gone through. In the above  example, I've made the naive assumption that a firm's cost of capital is  equivalent to the risk-free interest rate. In reality, this is not  true; it is however, a floor for the cost, in a sense, since if the cost  of capital is lower than the risk-free rate, it would make more  financial sense to invest in the risk-free asset since it's...risk-free  (there is perhaps a debate to be had if the US treasury is truly  risk-free, but the dollar is the world's reserve currency for the time  being at least, so it serves as a useful proxy)  When the Fed dropped  the interest rate in March, this is a very important input into a lot of  analysts valuation models. And since the value models are inversely  proportional to the interest rate, and the interest rate went down, the  valuations go up. The spot price of the SPY in Feb was around 320. If  nothing else had changed (i.e. the lockdowns hadn't occured and shot the  next few quarters of earnings) besides the interest rate, then the SPY  would have gone up based on this alone. Future cash flows are worth more  in the present in a low interest rate environment, it's that simply.  Now, there were lockdowns and that will undoubtedly factor in the future  earnings of companies, but for how long? A year? Two? Okay, but  valuation models are concerned with the entire lifetime of a company. At  some point, things will return to normal.

In  my simple model, I've shown how a drop in the ten year interest rate  from 1.6% to 0.9% can increase a firm's theoretical value by 75%. Some  more caveats. Earnings are not constant. It's the analyst's job to come  up with a plausible model for how these earnings fluctuate from quarter  to quarter. This can affect the valuation. The drop in March was  probably due to valuation models pricing in a few terrible quarters  worth of earnings. Now that the economy appears to be reopening, these  projections are probably being revised yet again to factor in new cash  flows in a lower interest rate environment.

Most  people in this thread don't seem to grasp the basics of valuation and  how it works, blaming the level of the market on the "Fed inflating the  money supply" or turning it into a meme. They see a  number going higher when the economy is full-on recession and think  this is counter-intuitive without understanding how the market actually  works. The market doesn't track the economy, it tracks valuations; the  economy affects valuations, but not in the straight forward way many  people seem to think.

Is the SP500  over-valued? Maybe, but not for any of the reasons cited in this  thread. There are signs institutions seem to think this might be the  case. One of my favorite indicators, the [SKEW Index](http://www.cboe.com/delayedquote/advanced-charts?ticker=^SKEW)  measures the probability distribution the market is assigning to  returns through their option purchases. A SKEW of 100 would correspond  to a return distribution that is perfectly normal, i.e. bell shaped. As  the SKEW creeps higher, the market begins to price in extreme return  probabilities, i.e. fatter tails. The SKEW has been trending up the past  few weeks, indicating that the market seems to think there is more  volatility ahead.

The [VIX future curve](http://vixcentral.com/)  recently went back into contango after a wild month, but it's only a  contango in the front months. There is a very large spike in October and  then the curve goes into backwardation again. Backwardation is usually  associated with extremely volatility times. For reference, the VIX curve  was in backwardation pretty much the entire month of March this year,  when the SP500 was whipsawing like crazy; the VIX's natural state during  an upward trend is contango, i.e. uncertainty increases with the time  horizon. The further you look into the future, the more uncertain you  are about the outcome. When things are backwardated, this means shit is  so crazy that volatility *has* to decrease. The fact that this recent rally has coincided with this strange shape in the VIX curve deserves some thought.

There  are other things I could mention, like companies not giving forward  guidance in their recent earnings reports but I've gone on long enough.  So...bye.

author: zg44
body:
Yes, the market is severely overvalued compared to the economy, even compared to February when things were already frothy.

But, we've seen many times over the past 25 years where the stock market can remain overextended for long periods when compared to underlying fundamentals.

This feels like one of those times, right now market is pricing in a full V recovery until it becomes clear that won't happen.  I think we have another 8-12 weeks until fundamentals have to re-exert themselves in the form of unemployment reports and other data that will be able to separate what the economy looks like without all the government support like PPP.

June and July unemployment reports should look good just on the basis of workers going back to their jobs.  After that we have to see what happens as all the economic lifelines are gradually stopped or pulled.  The government tossed trillions at the economy in 2 months, it does seem like that at least gives the semblance of a V shaped recovery on face, let's see if it sticks.  I hope it does for the sake of the US public, but I have doubts.  A lot of smaller businesses will not be back to anywhere near full monthly revenue by August.
